Recent advancements in generalized symmetries have drawn significant attention to gapped phases of matter
exhibiting novel symmetries, such as noninvertible symmetries. By leveraging the duality transformations, the
classification and construction of gapped phases with noninvertible symmetry can be mapped to those involving
conventional group symmetries. We demonstrate this approach by classifying symmetry-protected topological
phases with a broad class of noninvertible symmetries in arbitrary spacetime dimensions. Our results reveal new
classifications that extend beyond those based on group symmetries. Additionally, we construct lattice models
in (1 + 1)d and (2 + 1)d that realize these new phases and explore their anomalous interfaces.

ical bridges between different disciplines of physics.
Following the recent development of generalized sym-

with novel symmetries, such as subsystem symme-

As a sweeping generalization of symmetries, nonin-
vertible symmetries are described by fusion categories
and incorporate operations without an inverse.
Sur-
prisingly, noninvertible symmetries are ubiquitous in
physics and have significant applications in particle
physics [25–34] and quantum lattice models [35–57].
Recent progresses [58–63] also focus on realizing novel
quantum phases of matters with noninvertible symme-
tries, in preparation for future quantum devices [64].
A powerful and general method for finding gapped
phases, including SPTs, with noninvertible symmetries
utilizes duality transformations (for example gauging a
discrete symmetry) between models with symmetry C1
and C2.
The duality implies a one-to-one correspon-
dence between the equivalent classes of gapped phases
on the two sides. As an application, the gapped phases,
in particular SPTs, with symmetry C1, which might be
unknown, can be constructed and classified from the
duality and the gapped phases with symmetry C2. We
sketch this method in Fig. 1.

Conclusions.—We have demonstrated how to clas-
sify NISPTs from a duality transformation and the in-
formation of the gapped phases of a known symmetry
C2 = D2n through gauging a ZU
2 subgroup. Our results
provide a useful and clear way to understand the (higher)
fiber functor for (higher) categories.
Applying the duality method to lattice models, we
constructed new NISPTs in (1 + 1)d and (2 + 1)d and
studied their anomalous interfaces. In (1 + 1)d, we gave
a complete construction of Rep(D2n) SPTs. In (2+1)d,
we studied examples of 2-Rep(Z(1)
4
⋊Z(0)
2 ) SPTs to
demonstrate our method. We leave a thorough study of
NISPTs in higher dimensions to future research.
As a straightforward generalization, one can apply
such duality transformation to classify the other gapped
phases of noninvertible symmetries, such as noninvert-
ible symmetry-enriched topological orders [78]. More-
over, since gauging and duality transformations can be
realized as quantum operations [56] including measure-
ment [79–82], our method will be also useful for prepar-
ing NISPT states in quantum devices, e.g., Rydberg
atom arrays [64].

metadata.title: Duality viewpoint of noninvertible symmetry protected topological phases
metadata.abstract:
Recent advancements in generalized symmetries have drawn significant
attention to gapped phases of matter exhibiting novel symmetries, such as
noninvertible symmetries. By leveraging the duality transformations, the
classification and construction of gapped phases with noninvertible symmetry
can be mapped to those involving conventional group symmetries. We demonstrate
this approach by classifying symmetry-protected topological phases with a broad
class of noninvertible symmetries in arbitrary spacetime dimensions. Our
results reveal new classifications that extend beyond those based on group
symmetries. Additionally, we construct lattice models in $(1+1)d$ and $(2+1)d$
that realize these new phases and explore their anomalous interfaces.
